title: Getting help with NACHO
text: Thanks using NACHO. filing issue, places explore pieces put together make process smooth possible. Start making minimal reproducible example using reprex package. haven’t heard used reprex , ’re treat! Seriously, reprex make R-question-asking endeavors easier (pretty insane ROI five ten minutes ’ll take learn ’s ). additional reprex pointers, check Get help! section tidyverse site. opening new issue, sure search issues pull requests make sure bug hasn’t reported /already fixed development version. default, search pre-populated :issue :open. can edit qualifiers (e.g. :pr, :closed) needed. example, ’d simply remove :open search issues repo, open closed. right place, need file issue, please review “File issues” paragraph tidyverse contributing guidelines. title: NACHO Analysis
code: # Install NACHO from CRAN: install.packages("NACHO")  # Or the the development version from GitHub: # install.packages("remotes") remotes::install_github("mcanouil/NACHO")

title: NACHO Analysis
text: NACHO (NAnostring quality Control dasHbOard) developed NanoString nCounter data. NanoString nCounter data messenger-RNA/micro-RNA (mRNA/miRNA) expression assay works fluorescent barcodes. barcode assigned mRNA/miRNA, can counted bonding target. result count specific barcode represents presence target mRNA/miRNA. NACHO able load, visualise normalise exported NanoString nCounter data facilitates user performing quality control.NACHO visualising quality control metrics, expression control genes, principal components sample specific size factors interactive web application. use two functions, RCC files summarised visualised, namely: load_rcc() visualise(). load_rcc() function used preprocess data. visualise() function initiates Shiny-based dashboard visualises relevant QC plots. NACHO also includes function normalise(), (re)calculates sample specific size factors normalises data. normalise() function creates list settings, raw counts normalised counts stored. addition (since v0.6.0) NACHO includes two (three) additional functions: render() function renders full quality-control report (HTML) based results call load_rcc() normalise() (using print() Rmarkdown chunk). autoplot() function draws quality-control metrics visualise() render(). vignette("NACHO") vignette("NACHO-analysis"). Canouil M, Bouland GA, Bonnefond , Froguel P, Hart L, Slieker R (2019). “NACHO: R package quality control NanoString nCounter data.” Bioinformatics. ISSN 1367-4803, doi:10.1093/bioinformatics/btz647.
code: @Article{,   title = {{NACHO}: an {R} package for quality control of {NanoString} {nCounter} data},   author = {Mickaël Canouil and Gerard A. Bouland and Amélie Bonnefond and Philippe Froguel and Leen Hart and Roderick Slieker},   journal = {Bioinformatics},   address = {Oxford, England},   year = {2019},   month = {aug},   issn = {1367-4803},   doi = {10.1093/bioinformatics/btz647}, }

code: GSE70970 <- load_rcc(data_directory, targets, id_colname = "IDFILE") ## [NACHO] Importing RCC files. ## Error in load_rcc(data_directory, targets, id_colname = "IDFILE"): [NACHO] Multiple Nanostring file/software versions detected. ##   Please provide a set of files with the same version. ##   - FileVersion: '1.6', '1.6' ##   - SoftwareVersion: '2.1.2.3', '2.1.1.0005'

code: selected_pheno <- GSE70970[["nacho"]][   j = lapply(unique(.SD), function(x) ifelse(x == "NA", NA, x)),   .SDcols = c("IDFILE", "age:ch1", "gender:ch1", "chemo:ch1", "disease.event:ch1") ] ## Error in eval(expr, envir, enclos): object 'GSE70970' not found selected_pheno <- na.exclude(selected_pheno) ## Error in eval(expr, envir, enclos): object 'selected_pheno' not found ## Error in eval(expr, envir, enclos): object 'selected_pheno' not found

title: NACHO Analysis
text: Alternatively, "Accession" number also available.
code: expr_counts <- GSE70970[["nacho"]][   i = grepl("Endogenous", CodeClass),   j = as.matrix(     dcast(.SD, Name ~ IDFILE, value.var = "Count_Norm"),     "Name"   ),   .SDcols = c("IDFILE", "Name", "Count_Norm") ] ## Error in eval(expr, envir, enclos): object 'GSE70970' not found ## Error in eval(expr, envir, enclos): object 'expr_counts' not found GSE70970[["nacho"]][   i = grepl("Endogenous", CodeClass),   j = as.matrix(     dcast(.SD, Accession ~ IDFILE, value.var = "Count_Norm"),     "Accession"   ),   .SDcols = c("IDFILE", "Accession", "Count_Norm") ]

title: NACHO Analysis
text: Make sure count matrix phenotypes samples Build numeric design matrix limma
code: samples_kept <- intersect(selected_pheno[["IDFILE"]], colnames(expr_counts)) ## Error in h(simpleError(msg, call)): error in evaluating the argument 'x' in selecting a method for function 'intersect': object 'selected_pheno' not found expr_counts <- expr_counts[, samples_kept] ## Error in eval(expr, envir, enclos): object 'expr_counts' not found selected_pheno <- selected_pheno[IDFILE %in% c(samples_kept)] ## Error in eval(expr, envir, enclos): object 'selected_pheno' not found design <- model.matrix(~ `disease.event:ch1`, selected_pheno) ## Error in eval(expr, envir, enclos): object 'selected_pheno' not found eBayes(lmFit(expr_counts, design)) ## Error in eval(expr, envir, enclos): object 'expr_counts' not found

what: Perform the analyses using lm (or any other model)
title: NACHO Analysis
code: GSE70970[["nacho"]][   i = grepl("Endogenous", CodeClass),   j = lapply(unique(.SD), function(x) ifelse(x == "NA", NA, x)),   .SDcols = c(     "IDFILE", "Name", "Accession", "Count", "Count_Norm",     "age:ch1", "gender:ch1", "chemo:ch1", "disease.event:ch1"   ) ][   Name %in% head(unique(Name), 10) ][   j = as.data.table(     coef(summary(lm(       formula = Count_Norm ~ `disease.event:ch1`,       data = na.exclude(.SD)     ))),     "term"   ),   by = c("Name", "Accession") ] ## Error in eval(expr, envir, enclos): object 'GSE70970' not found

NACHO able load, visualise normalise exported NanoString nCounter data facilitates user performing quality control.NACHO visualising quality control metrics, expression control genes, principal components sample specific size factors interactive web application. use two functions, RCC files summarised visualised, namely: load_rcc() visualise(). load_rcc() function used preprocess data. visualise() function initiates Shiny-based dashboard visualises relevant QC plots. NACHO also includes function normalise(), (re)calculates sample specific size factors normalises data. normalise() function creates list settings, raw counts normalised counts stored. addition (since v0.6.0) NACHO includes two (three) additional functions: render() function renders full quality-control report (HTML) based results call load_rcc() normalise() (using print() Rmarkdown chunk). autoplot() function draws quality-control metrics visualise() render(). vignette("NACHO") vignette("NACHO-analysis"). title: NACHO
text: first argument requires path directory containing RCC files, second argument location samplesheet followed third argument column name containing exact names files. housekeeping_genes normalisation_method arguments respectively indicate housekeeping genes normalisation method used.
code: GSE70970_sum <- load_rcc(   data_directory = file.path(tempdir(), "GSE70970", "Data"), # Where the data is   ssheet_csv = targets, # The samplesheet   id_colname = "IDFILE", # Name of the column that contains the unique identfiers   housekeeping_genes = NULL, # Custom list of housekeeping genes   housekeeping_predict = TRUE, # Whether or not to predict the housekeeping genes   normalisation_method = "GEO", # Geometric mean or GLM   n_comp = 5 # Number indicating how many principal components should be computed. ) ## [NACHO] Importing RCC files. ## Error in load_rcc(data_directory = file.path(tempdir(), "GSE70970", "Data"), : [NACHO] Multiple Nanostring file/software versions detected. ##   Please provide a set of files with the same version. ##   - FileVersion: '1.6', '1.6' ##   - SoftwareVersion: '2.1.2.3', '2.1.1.0005'

title: NACHO
text: autoplot() function provides easy way plot quality-control visualise() function. possible metrics (x) : "BD" (Binding Density) "FoV" (Imaging) "PCL" (Positive Control Linearity) "LoD" (Limit Detection) "Positive" (Positive Controls) "Negative" (Negative Controls) "Housekeeping" (Housekeeping Genes) "PN" (Positive Controls vs. Negative Controls) "ACBD" (Average Counts vs. Binding Density) "ACMC" (Average Counts vs. Median Counts) "PCA12" (Principal Component 1 vs. 2) "PCAi" (Principal Component scree plot) "PCA" (Principal Components planes) "PFNF" (Positive Factor vs. Negative Factor) "HF" (Housekeeping Factor) "NORM" (Normalisation Factor)
code: autoplot(   object = GSE74821,   x = "BD",   colour = "CartridgeID",   size = 0.5,   show_legend = TRUE )

title: NanoString Quality Control Dashboard
text: NACHO (NAnostring quality Control dasHbOard) developed NanoString nCounter data. NanoString nCounter data messenger-RNA/micro-RNA (mRNA/miRNA) expression assay works fluorescent barcodes. barcode assigned mRNA/miRNA, can counted bonding target. result count specific barcode represents presence target mRNA/miRNA. NACHO able load, visualise normalise exported NanoString nCounter data facilitates user performing quality control.NACHO visualising quality control metrics, expression control genes, principal components sample specific size factors interactive web application. use two functions, RCC files summarised visualised, namely: load_rcc() visualise(). load_rcc() function used preprocess data. visualise() function initiates Shiny-based dashboard visualises relevant QC plots. NACHO also includes function normalise(), (re)calculates sample specific size factors normalises data. normalise() function creates list settings, raw counts normalised counts stored. addition (since v0.6.0) NACHO includes two (three) additional functions: render() function renders full quality-control report (HTML) based results call load_rcc() normalise() (using print() Rmarkdown chunk). autoplot() function draws quality-control metrics visualise() render(). vignette("NACHO") vignette("NACHO-analysis").

title: NACHO: NanoString Quality Control Dashboard — NACHO-package
text: NanoString nCounter data gene expression assays need use enzymes amplification protocols work fluorescent barcodes (Geiss et al. (2018) doi:10.1038/nbt1385 ). barcode assigned messenger-RNA/micro-RNA (mRNA/miRNA) bonding target can counted. result count specific barcode represents presence target mRNA/miRNA. 'NACHO' (NAnoString quality Control dasHbOard) able analyse exported NanoString nCounter data facilitates user performing quality control. 'NACHO' visualising quality control metrics, expression control genes, principal components sample specific size factors interactive web application.

title: Plot quality-control metrics and thresholds of a
text: object [list] List obtained load_rcc() normalise(). x [character] Character string naming quality-control metrics plot nacho_object. possible values : "BD" (Binding Density) "FoV" (Imaging) "PCL" (Positive Control Linearity) "LoD" (Limit Detection) "Positive" (Positive Controls) "Negative" (Negative Controls) "Housekeeping" (Housekeeping Genes) "PN" (Positive Controls vs. Negative Controls) "ACBD" (Average Counts vs. Binding Density) "ACMC" (Average Counts vs. Median Counts) "PCA12" (Principal Component 1 vs. 2) "PCAi" (Principal Component scree plot) "PCA" (Principal Components planes) "PFNF" (Positive Factor vs. Negative Factor) "HF" (Housekeeping Factor) "NORM" (Normalisation Factor) colour [character] Character string column ssheet_csv generally nacho_object$nacho used grouping colour. size [numeric] numeric controlling point size (ggplot2::geom_point() line size (ggplot2::geom_line()). show_legend [logical] Boolean indicate whether plot legends plotted (TRUE) (FALSE). Default TRUE. show_outliers [logical] Boolean indicate whether outliers highlighted red (TRUE) (FALSE). Default TRUE. outliers_factor [numeric] Size factor outliers compared size. Default 1. outliers_labels [character] Character indicate column nacho_object$nacho used printed labels outliers . Default NULL. ... arguments (used).

title: Produce a
text: function used preprocess data NanoString nCounter.

title: Produce a
code: load_rcc(   data_directory,   ssheet_csv,   id_colname = NULL,   housekeeping_genes = NULL,   housekeeping_predict = FALSE,   housekeeping_norm = TRUE,   normalisation_method = "GEO",   n_comp = 10 )

title: Produce a
text: data_directory [character] character string directory data stored. ssheet_csv [character] [data.frame] Either string name CSV samplesheet samplesheet data.frame. contain column matches file names folder. id_colname [character] Character string column ssheet_csv matches file names data_directory. housekeeping_genes [character] vector names miRNAs/mRNAs used housekeeping genes. Default NULL. housekeeping_predict [logical] Boolean indicate whether housekeeping genes predicted (TRUE) (FALSE). Default FALSE. housekeeping_norm [logical] Boolean indicate whether housekeeping normalisation performed. Default TRUE. normalisation_method [character] Either "GEO" "GLM". Character string indicate normalisation using geometric mean ("GEO") generalized linear model ("GLM"). Default "GEO". n_comp [numeric] Number indicating number principal components compute. n-1 samples. Default 10.

title: Produce a
text: [list] list object class "nacho": access [character] Value passed load_rcc() id_colname. housekeeping_genes [character] Value passed load_rcc(). housekeeping_predict [logical] Value passed load_rcc(). housekeeping_norm [logical] Value passed load_rcc(). normalisation_method [character] Value passed load_rcc(). remove_outliers [logical] FALSE. n_comp [numeric] Value passed load_rcc(). data_directory [character] Value passed load_rcc(). pc_sum [data.frame] data.frame n_comp rows four columns: "Standard deviation", "Proportion Variance", "Cumulative Proportion" "PC". nacho [data.frame] data.frame columns sample sheet ssheet_csv computed columns, .e., quality-control metrics counts, one sample per row. outliers_thresholds [list] list (default) quality-control thresholds used.

title: Produce a
code: if (interactive()) {   library(GEOquery)   library(NACHO)    # Import data from GEO   gse <- GEOquery::getGEO(GEO = "GSE74821")   targets <- Biobase::pData(Biobase::phenoData(gse[[1]]))   GEOquery::getGEOSuppFiles(GEO = "GSE74821", baseDir = tempdir())   utils::untar(     tarfile = file.path(tempdir(), "GSE74821", "GSE74821_RAW.tar"),     exdir = file.path(tempdir(), "GSE74821")   )   targets$IDFILE <- list.files(     path = file.path(tempdir(), "GSE74821"),     pattern = ".RCC.gz$"   )   targets[] <- lapply(X = targets, FUN = iconv, from = "latin1", to = "ASCII")   utils::write.csv(     x = targets,     file = file.path(tempdir(), "GSE74821", "Samplesheet.csv")   )    # Read RCC files and format   nacho <- load_rcc(     data_directory = file.path(tempdir(), "GSE74821"),     ssheet_csv = file.path(tempdir(), "GSE74821", "Samplesheet.csv"),     id_colname = "IDFILE"   ) }

title: (re)Normalise a
text: function creates list settings, raw counts normalised counts stored, using result call load_rcc().

title: (re)Normalise a
code: normalise(   nacho_object,   housekeeping_genes = nacho_object[["housekeeping_genes"]],   housekeeping_predict = nacho_object[["housekeeping_predict"]],   housekeeping_norm = nacho_object[["housekeeping_norm"]],   normalisation_method = nacho_object[["normalisation_method"]],   n_comp = nacho_object[["n_comp"]],   remove_outliers = nacho_object[["remove_outliers"]],   outliers_thresholds = nacho_object[["outliers_thresholds"]] )

title: (re)Normalise a
text: nacho_object [list] list object class "nacho" obtained load_rcc() normalise(). housekeeping_genes [character] vector names miRNAs/mRNAs used housekeeping genes. Default NULL. housekeeping_predict [logical] Boolean indicate whether housekeeping genes predicted (TRUE) (FALSE). Default FALSE. housekeeping_norm [logical] Boolean indicate whether housekeeping normalisation performed. Default TRUE. normalisation_method [character] Either "GEO" "GLM". Character string indicate normalisation using geometric mean ("GEO") generalized linear model ("GLM"). Default "GEO". n_comp [numeric] Number indicating number principal components compute. n-1 samples. Default 10. remove_outliers [logical] boolean indicate outliers excluded. outliers_thresholds [list] List thresholds exclude outliers.

title: (re)Normalise a
text: [list] list containing parameters data. access [character] Value passed load_rcc() id_colname. housekeeping_genes [character] Value passed load_rcc() normalise(). housekeeping_predict [logical] Value passed load_rcc(). housekeeping_norm [logical] Value passed load_rcc() normalise(). normalisation_method [character] Value passed load_rcc() normalise(). remove_outliers [logical] Value passed normalise(). n_comp [numeric] Value passed load_rcc(). data_directory [character] Value passed load_rcc(). pc_sum [data.frame] data.frame n_comp rows four columns: "Standard deviation", "Proportion Variance", "Cumulative Proportion" "PC". nacho [data.frame] data.frame columns sample sheet ssheet_csv computed columns, .e., quality-control metrics counts, one sample per row. outliers_thresholds [list] list quality-control thresholds used. raw_counts [data.frame] Raw counts probes rows samples columns. "CodeClass" (first column), type probes "Name" (second column), Name probes. normalised_counts [data.frame] Normalised counts probes rows samples columns. "CodeClass" (first column)), type probes "Name" (second column), name probes.

title: (re)Normalise a
text: Outliers definition (remove_outliers = TRUE): Binding Density (BD) < 0.1 Binding Density (BD) > 2.25 Field View (FoV) < 75 Positive Control Linearity (PCL) < 0.95 Limit Detection (LoD) < 2 Positive normalisation factor (Positive_factor) < 0.25 Positive normalisation factor (Positive_factor) > 4 Housekeeping normalisation factor (house_factor) < 1/11 Housekeeping normalisation factor (house_factor) > 11

title: (re)Normalise a
code: data(GSE74821) GSE74821_norm <- normalise(   nacho_object = GSE74821,   housekeeping_norm = TRUE,   normalisation_method = "GEO",   remove_outliers = TRUE ) #> [NACHO] Normalising "GSE74821" with new value for parameters: #>   - normalisation_method = TRUE #>   - remove_outliers = TRUE #> [NACHO] Computing normalisation factors using "GEO" method. #> [NACHO] Returning a list. #>   $ access              : character #>   $ housekeeping_genes  : character #>   $ housekeeping_predict: logical #>   $ housekeeping_norm   : logical #>   $ normalisation_method: character #>   $ remove_outliers     : logical #>   $ n_comp              : numeric #>   $ data_directory      : character #>   $ pc_sum              : data.frame #>   $ nacho               : data.frame #>   $ outliers_thresholds : list  if (interactive()) {   library(GEOquery)   library(NACHO)    # Import data from GEO   gse <- GEOquery::getGEO(GEO = "GSE74821")   targets <- Biobase::pData(Biobase::phenoData(gse[[1]]))   GEOquery::getGEOSuppFiles(GEO = "GSE74821", baseDir = tempdir())   utils::untar(     tarfile = file.path(tempdir(), "GSE74821", "GSE74821_RAW.tar"),     exdir = file.path(tempdir(), "GSE74821")   )   targets$IDFILE <- list.files(     path = file.path(tempdir(), "GSE74821"),     pattern = ".RCC.gz$"   )   targets[] <- lapply(X = targets, FUN = iconv, from = "latin1", to = "ASCII")   utils::write.csv(     x = targets,     file = file.path(tempdir(), "GSE74821", "Samplesheet.csv")   )    # Read RCC files and format   nacho <- load_rcc(     data_directory = file.path(tempdir(), "GSE74821"),     ssheet_csv = file.path(tempdir(), "GSE74821", "Samplesheet.csv"),     id_colname = "IDFILE"   )    # (re)Normalise data by removing outliers   nacho_norm <- normalise(     nacho_object = nacho,     remove_outliers = TRUE   )    # (re)Normalise data with "GLM" method and removing outliers   nacho_norm <- normalise(     nacho_object = nacho,     normalisation_method = "GLM",     remove_outliers = TRUE   ) }

Default TRUE. show_outliers [logical] Boolean indicate whether outliers highlighted red (TRUE) (FALSE). Default TRUE. outliers_factor [numeric] Size factor outliers compared size. Default 1. outliers_labels [character] Character indicate column nacho_object$nacho used printed labels outliers . Default NULL. echo [logical] boolean indicate whether text plots printed. Mainly use within Rmarkdown chunk. title_level [numeric] numeric indicate title level start , using markdown style, .e., number "#". xaringan [logical] boolean format output Xaringan slides. ... arguments (used).

title: Visualise quality-control metrics of a
code: if (interactive()) {   data(GSE74821)   # Must be run in an interactive R session!   visualise(GSE74821) }  if (interactive()) {   library(GEOquery)   library(NACHO)    # Import data from GEO   gse <- GEOquery::getGEO(GEO = "GSE74821")   targets <- Biobase::pData(Biobase::phenoData(gse[[1]]))   GEOquery::getGEOSuppFiles(GEO = "GSE74821", baseDir = tempdir())   utils::untar(     tarfile = file.path(tempdir(), "GSE74821", "GSE74821_RAW.tar"),     exdir = file.path(tempdir(), "GSE74821")   )   targets$IDFILE <- list.files(     path = file.path(tempdir(), "GSE74821"),     pattern = ".RCC.gz$"   )   targets[] <- lapply(X = targets, FUN = iconv, from = "latin1", to = "ASCII")   utils::write.csv(     x = targets,     file = file.path(tempdir(), "GSE74821", "Samplesheet.csv")   )    # Read RCC files and format   nacho <- load_rcc(     data_directory = file.path(tempdir(), "GSE74821"),     ssheet_csv = file.path(tempdir(), "GSE74821", "Samplesheet.csv"),     id_colname = "IDFILE"   )   visualise(nacho)    # (re)Normalise data by removing outliers   nacho_norm <- normalise(     nacho_object = nacho,     remove_outliers = TRUE   )   visualise(nacho_norm)    # (re)Normalise data with "GLM" method and removing outliers   nacho_norm <- normalise(     nacho_object = nacho,     normalisation_method = "GLM",     remove_outliers = TRUE   )   visualise(nacho_norm) }
